rASTUx-y5.memHandModelNotes: 'Apalachicola nests' distance from the nearest water averaged 12 m. The one nest on an island in Lake Iamonia was in the open and was 72 m from the nearest water. Ewert and Jackson (1994) expanded this data set but not greatly altered these proportions. Jackson and Jensen (2003) reported nest sites that were about 30 and 70 m from streams (NatureServe 2005).' In Tennessee, F. Scott (pers. comm., 1992) most often found radio-tagged turtles in less than 3 m of water (NatureServe 2005).  ******Modeling : Since species aquatic use hydrology layers to build model.  Did not select MU's rather select all open water pixels and forested or shrub/scrub that fall within the hydro buffer. Amy Silvano 2jul05.

habitat_description:
The alligator snapping turtle is primarily distributed in river systems of the southeastern United States that drain into the Gulf of Mexico. The range includes all rivers from southern Georgia, northwestern Florida, to west Louisiana, and eastern Texas. Also the river systems of southeastern Iowa, Illinois, southern Indiana, and southeastern Kansas (Boundy and Kennedy 2006; Conant and Collins 1991; Jensen and Birkhead 2003; Johnson 1989; Lovich 1993).

This species is known to burrow in or using soil. Preferred habitats consist of slow-moving streams, deep waters of rivers, sloughs, oxbows, canals, and minor streams. Also found in ponds near rivers, shallow creeks, tributaries, swift upland streams, impoundments, and bayous (Ernst et al. 2004; Natureserve.org; Phelps 2004). Generally, alligator snapping turtles occupy river mouths, tidal rivers, big rivers, but also deep and shallow water pools. Riparian habitats include forested wetland, although rare to find them outside of the water except for nesting (Natureserve.org). This species is found under or in logjams, under rock shelter, in deep holes, or beneath undercut banks (Jensen et al. 2008).

“Alligator snapping turtles tend to be distributed in a more or less linear fashion along riverine systems, with most nesting on high ground in streamside locations” (Jackson and Ewert 1994 (as referenced by Natureserve.org)).
